THE NEW YORK & PORTO RICO STEAMSHIP COMPANY
B
PORTO RICO LINE
II BROADWAY, NEW YORK
CABLE ADDRESS “NEWTORICO”
ON BOARD S. S. BRAZOS Sept 23 1916

div1.p:
I judge that my letter written to you
from San Juan is aboard this boat. Pos
& you will get this at the same time you get
that. The one I wrote you from La Caracas
ought to have arrived in N. Y. yesterday
& go down on the Fruit S. S. before this one
does - but I don't know maybe you
will get them all at once!

I am writing this to tell you (1) what has
happened & (2) future plans.

(1) We could not get passage on the S. S. R. Janiero
(Brazilian Lloyd) at San Juan - every berth
taken in N. Y. so all of us except Guiteras
Came has- are aboard this vessel & I will
be able to go to Baltimore for a few days
-3 to 5- if with present indications.

(2) I will probably (almost certainly) sail by
the S.S. Minas Geräes - billed to leave N. Y.
Oct 4- pick up Guiteras at San Juan
& go to one of the Coast town - Bahia proba-
bly. The “Coast towns” we ought to visit are
Para - Bahia & Pernambuco. Gorgas, Lys-
ter & Wrightson & Mrs G. will take the
Lampfort & Holt S. S. (Oct 7) for Rio di
rect. We (G & I) will simply do what we
can unofficially until me we Gorgas has

the approval of the Central Authorities.
His (Gorgas's) Partner will come up from Rio &
together we will finish the coast towns
& then (a) if there be time enough
all of us go up to Mañaos, (b) if there
be not time enough. Guiteras & myself
(& possibly W.) will gos up the Amazon
to Mañaos & Iquitos, & O the rest of the
party go home. Gorgas & Lyster appa-
rently must be in Washington on Dec.
10 - 6 months leave. My own, & ‘Wrightson's
leave (without pay) is not so limited. Guite
Guiteras
C1
B21
4
Guiteras too can stay. If (a) takes place
i.e. we all go to Mañaos - there will surely
not, be time enough, to go to Iquitos & get
back by Dec 10, so, I & Guiteras (& possibly
Wrightson) would keep on to Iquitos by
our self selves & arrive say 10 or 14 days
later. I hope before Xmas however.
That is the present tentative plan. It
may be altered when we reach N. Y.
I think not

We have had a beautiful trip from
San Juan - this is the 3d day - We ran
through the edge of a Cyclone, the
first 2 days. The center was East by N.
of us at first, yesterday morning E by s S. E.
now we are pretty well out of it - center is
south or S. by W. There was a free Wind
C1
B21
5
nearly ahead & a tremendous swell
nearly at right angles to the wind.
Spray flying over every thing - You
would have enjoyed it & I'd have
given 50 dollars had you been with
us. The We have 284 passengers - Pa Do-
Rigneños going up to school - The very
best thing for the Island & for the U. S.
which could happen - They didn't en-
joy it. They are out today however - &
very a very pretty lot of baby-faced chil-
dren'- (high-school age) they are & & how
they
6
they are chattering!

I am very glad to get to Baltimore & I espe-
cially in view of the long Amazon trip
2 1/2 months about - possibly 3 - not so long
however as I have been absent.
I am of course getting no great deal, when
it is “leave without-pay”- about $9.00 per
day more than my salary. The
Army men get 3/4 pay no matter how long
their have runs & yet, under they to
laylaw they are only due 4 months leave
with pay - thye same as we are. I will see to this
when I get to Washington.

I am quite well & send a registered
letter for the Ostrich feather from San
Juan - Judge there will be duty on
it. Love to the Huricks
div1.closer:
Very truly y
your daddy H. R. Carter By the way, Mr Wakefield is absolutely satis-
fied with the “storm at sea” he
has just been
through. It was no storm, but a
heavy swell- higher than the deck - & he was
very sea sick for 2 days & nights.
This is just to give you news
H. R. C.
